title: React component's generics lost when use fowardRef
description: React component's generics lost when use forwardRef method. It is a bug. Solution: Use the fixed fowardRef function type to override the original one.

children.value: React component's generics lost when use forwardRef method. It is a bug. Solution: Use the fixed fowardRef function type to override the original one.

title: npm library type module and exports
description: The fields of package.json for npm library.

children.value: The fields of package.json for npm library.
The fields of package.json for npm library.

Previously, we used "main" and "module". "main" refers to the main entry point, usually in cjs format. "module" refers to the esm entry point. Note that only bundling tools like webpack and rollup support "module", while Node.js only supports "main". If you directly run the node command like
, and your js file imports a library, Node.js will only call the file corresponding to the library's "main" field.

props.className: language-json shiki shiki-themes solarized-light github-dark monokai

children.value: "." represents the main entry point, which is the "main" and "module" mentioned above. The "import" field in the child level refers to the esm file, the "require" field refers to the cjs file, and the "types" field refers to the type definition file.

Unfortunately, "exports" is supported by Node.js and major bundling tools, but not by the current stable version of TypeScript (4.5). TypeScript 4.7 already supports it, but the built-in version of vscode is 4.5. So when using vscode, the type definition files in "exports" cannot be found.
Therefore, if your library has multiple entry points and each entry point has its own type definition file, I suggest you not to do it this way, but to publish them as different npm libraries.

props.className: language-json shiki shiki-themes solarized-light github-dark monokai

children.value: , the exported cjs file has the 'cjs' extension.

title: Configuring Nuxt3 and @nuxtjs/i18n v8 Multilingual Module, and Common Pitfalls
description: These days, I have been itching to refactor my blog using Nuxt3.7 and configure multi-language functionality using @nuxtjs/i18n v8. During the configuration process, I encountered some challenges, so I decided to write down some notes.

children.value: These days, I have been itching to refactor my blog using Nuxt3.7 and configure multi-language functionality using
v8. During the configuration process, I encountered some challenges, so I decided to write down some notes.
These days, I have been itching to refactor my blog using Nuxt3.7 and configure multi-language functionality using
v8. During the configuration process, I encountered some challenges, so I decided to write down some notes.
I wanted to add language-prefixed routes for the existing routes. For example, after adding the language
, the home page should automatically register the route

. After configuring according to the official documentation, everything else was working fine except for the routes. By the way, Nuxt comes with a built-in in-browser development tool that allows you to view the registered routes. You can click on the floating Nuxt icon on the page or press the
After a few hours of tinkering, I finally succeeded. As for why I had to do it this way, I have no idea. Here's how I wrote it in

props.className: language-ts shiki shiki-themes solarized-light github-dark monokai

children.value: // default locale of your project for Nuxt pages and routings
. This configuration works fine. Previously, I had all the
, which caused the issue of not adding routes for other languages.
has several routing strategies, and I am using the default strategy here.
There was a bug in the
version I used these days. When running
, an error occurred. Installing the latest version fixed the issue.

. I must say, this component is not mentioned on the page where the
function is documented, nor is it included in the navigation menu on the left sidebar.
